lines.text: Arlena and I were in the chorus of a show together, not that I could ever compete. Even in those days, she could always throw her legs up in the air higher than any of us... and wider.
I'm better now. In fact, I'm determined to enjoy myself. It's so blissful here, so tranquil, so far from all violence and trouble.
Yes, you are right, Madame; the sky is blue, the sun is shining, and yet you forget that everywhere there is evil under the sun.
Oh, dear! I'm the last to arrive.
Have a sausage. You must be starving having to wait all that time in your room.

[needling about financial loss caused by Arlena leaving their show]
Anyway darlings, it must have cost you a pretty bundle closing a hit show like that. Would either of you care to comment on that?
Why don't you go and play with yourself.
Excessively.
Is coarseness a substitute for wit, I ask myself?
[last lines]
I've just had a phone call from His Majesty and he is very pleased with...
The king of Tyrania?
He is very pleased with the matter being cleared up so quickly and so discreetly. He is so pleased he is awarding you the Order of Saint Gudrun the Inquisitive.
Saint Gudrun the Inquisitive?
First class.
How many classes are there?
Hercules Parrot, sir!

[entering the office]
Poirot, Mademoiselle, pucker your lips as though about to bestow a kiss! Poi-rot.

[to Linda Marshall]
Linda do stop standing there like a coughdrop and say good morning to Monsieur Poirot!
The "Arlena Stewarts" of this world do not count; their domination is of the moment. Really to count, a woman must have either goodness or brains.
You can't actually believe that men care for either of those things, can you?
Oh yes I do, madam.

[arriving at outdoor buffet luncheon in swimming attire]
I'm so sorry, are we late? Patrick insisted upon rowing me right round the island and its much bigger than I thought. Poor darling, he's absolutely exhausted.

[dryly, knowing what they've actually been up to]
I'm not in the least surprised.

[to the killer]
You see, it is folly to try and trick Hercule Poirot... even in a dead language.
Couldn't we make this a private investigation? You know how peculiar people can be about a spot of murder.
I was wrong about cherchez la femme. sorry about that. but it's just got be cherchez le fruit.
It's funny to think if Giuseppe Verdi had been an Englishman his name would have been Joe Green.

[Thoughtfully]
Yes, I suppose it would, yes.
Well it used to make the boys laugh when I was trying to din some Latin into them when I was a school teacher.
Little boys laugh easily if it keeps them away even for a moment from their study of Latin.
I've just had a telephone call from your friend Sir Horace. He says he's having trouble with his... his... his piffle valve?
Such a valve still has to be invented, Madame.
Oh, well I dare say you're right, I wasn't paying that much attention, anyway the result is he'll be 24 hours late.

[a little too solicitously, about Linda's step-mother, Arlena]
And how is your lovely mother, this morning?
She's not lovely and she's not my mother!
Clean it, clean it. Don't just lean on the thing.
Thank you for those three hours of sheer, and unadulterated hell! This may come as a nasty surprise to you but shock absorbers have been standardized equipment on motorized vehicles for thirty years!

[notices Poirot in lobby]
Oh, you - you must be Sir Horace Blatt's friend; perhaps - perhaps you'll sign in?
[signs hotel register]
Oh, so you're the famous Hercule Poirot eh?
Ah you are too amiable madame.

[sternly]
Perhaps - I hope you haven't come here to practice your sleuthing games on my guests - they've all got far too many skeletons in their cupboards to join in with enthusiasm.
It is not me that is hiding, it is you who are lying!
[Poirot is interrogating the suspects]
It's a little difficult to accept your condolences, Poirot... when in the same breath you accuse me of murdering my wife because she was unfaithful.

[matter of factly]
I can understand that, of course.
What's it called, anyway?
It's not right and it's not fair.
Sounds like a blackman's left leg.
Are you all comfortable? Even the murderer?

[watching people sunbathing on the beach]
How I wish I could do that, just lie in the sun.
Mais porquoi, madame? Look at them lying in rows, like corpses at the morgue! They are not men and women. Nothing personal about them. They're just bodies, butcher's meat, steaks grilling in the sun.
Well, what the hell do we do now, Odell?
Just leave it to me. I'll think of something.
Hmmph, my hero. I swear, if you were a man I would divorce you.
I only touched the body to make sure it was dead.

[as he sites a sunbather who could be either his wife or Arlena]
Look. I wonder who that is.
You know exactly who it is, you naughty boy.
[No, he really was wondering]
The whole world knows that you are a man of enormous discretion...

[greeting the Redferns]
Hello! I'm Daphne Castle - welcome to the island.
How do you do.

[unenthusiastic]
It looks lovely, I'm sure we'll have a nice time here.

[twinkling]
And a naughty one too - I hope!

[the guilty Christine Redfern]
A picture of innocence.
There she goes, not a care in the world.
I'll make her care.
Oh, what do you know about care? If it had been up to you, the good Samaritan would have passed by on the other side.
I have an idea but I need to work it out.
Yeah, well don't forget about my cousin, Hatty Heimenheimer. It took her so long to "work out an idea," they finally had to stash her away in the booby hatch!
